eDNA was going to be my summer project in an environmental management masters in 2020. My plan was to compare traditional otter tracking methods with eDNA analysis for wild otters along the River Trent in England. Unfortunately the pandemic put a stop to the whole degree before I could get out there and take any samples.
The more I hear about eDNA analysis the more amazing it sounds. Of course it's useless without also having massive genetic libraries and DNA primers. You have to be careful to be both not too selective in what you're looking for but also not so broad that your readings get swamped with too much data.
A lot of the technology for eDNA analysis still relies on huge centralised labs but it should be theoretically possible to make off-the-shelf eDNA analysis tools that work the same way as lateral flow and PCR Covid test kits, which would be very handy for large-scale or industrial tracking of invasive or endangered species.
Same concept as sampling sewage to get a rough indication of how prevalent covid and other infections are in a given neighborhood.

The wastewater treatment plant of my small town started monitoring for the DNA sequence of covid within the household wastewater last fall. They even detected the Omicron variant in early December even tho there wasn't any confirmed case till later that month. In the future, they plan to use wastewater as an early detection system for different kinds of diseases.
